_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Calumet Montana Refining

Risk Management Plan

Executive Summary





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES (40 CFR 68.155 (a))

Calumet Montana Refining, LLC (CMR) owns and operates a petroleum refinery alongside the Missouri River in Great Falls, Montana.  CMR has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our facility.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls in the event a release does occur, our trained personnel will respond to prevent and mitigate any releases of regulated substances. Due to the complexity of the refining processes and the hazardous substances involved, there are potential hazards to both the public and the environment that must be properly managed to protect the welfare of the surrounding community. As a result, CMR has developed and continuously implements its Process Safety Management (PSM) program and Risk Management Program (RMP) to mitigate potential risks throughout the useful life of its equipment. This Risk Management Plan is intended to comply with the requirements of EPA's Risk Management Program.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED (40 CFR 68.155 (b))

The refinery is comprised of multiple processes used to refine crude oil into various grades of motor gasoline, diesel fuels, jet fuels, and asphalt products. These processes involve materials that EPA has specifically designated as either toxic or flammable.  The RMP-regulated flammable substances held above threshold quantities at the refinery include:  butane; 1-butene; ethane; ethylene; hydrogen; isobutane; isopentane; methane; 2-methyl, 1-butene; pentane; trans-2-pentene; cis-2pentene; propane; and propylene. Hydrofluoric acid is the toxic substance managed in a quantity above the RMP threshold quantity. These substances may ex

ist in pure form or, more commonly, as part of mixtures at varying concentrations.



Release Scenarios

The following sections will describe the worst-case and alternative release scenarios for both toxic and flammable substances. RMP*Comp was used to model each release scenario and MARPLOT was used to estimate the impacted population.



Toxic Worst-Case

The worst-case toxic release scenario involves the catastrophic rupture of the hydrofluoric acid storage vessel (D-1504). This vessel is assumed to catastrophically rupture and release its entire contents (76,917.2 pounds of HF) over a 10-minute period. The endpoint distance associated with this toxic worst-case release scenario is 11.0 miles and this scenario has the potential to impact 73,129 individuals in addition to other sensitive receptors (e.g. schools, light commercial areas, etc.).



Toxic Alternative

The alternative toxic release scenario selected is operator error during hydrofluoric acid unloading that results in 10,000 pounds of HF being released over a 10-minute period. The endpoint distance associated with this release is 1.6 miles and approximately 18,670 individuals may be impacted by this scenario along with other sensitive receptors.

Flammable Worst-Case



The worst-case scenario chosen to represent flammable substances is the catastrophic rupture of one of the LPG storage vessels (Tank No. 3).  The scenario assumes that the entire quantity of flammable material (isobutane) at maximum storage conditions (353,525 pounds) is released over a 10-minute period. The scenario concludes with a vapor cloud explosion which results in an endpoint distance of 0.6 miles and approximately 1,066 individuals impacted.

Flammable Alternative



The alternative scenario selected to represent all flammable substances is associated with component failure at the Syn Gas Tower (T-0301) in the FCCU unit. The scenario assumes that the entire quantity of flammable material (gasoline) at maximum storage conditions

(14,500 pounds) is released followed by a vapor cloud explosion. This scenario has an endpoint distance of 0.2 miles. MARPLOT did not identify any individuals that could be impacted by this scenario; however, the scenario could have offsite impacts on the northeast corner of the facility including traffic on Smelter Avenue and 10th Street and businesses at that same intersection.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS (40 CFR 68.155 (c))

CMR has processes subject to the Occupational Safety & Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation 1910.119 and the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP).  The plant adheres to all applicable federal and state regulatory statutes.  The plant has established programs based on OSHA PSM to evaluate and identify potential risk through management of change and mechanical integrity programs and process hazard assessments.



Actions to minimize potential releases are facilitated by having trained personnel who participate in the programs; the use of qualified contractors; and by utilizing documented operating procedures, pre-start-up safety reviews, and established safe work practices. Incidents are investigated and compliance audits performed to periodically assess the programs. The processes at CMR have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation. Collectively, accident prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by (1) equipment failures and (2) human errors. In addition to the accident prevention program activities, process safety features exist on many units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release. The following types of safety features are used in various processes:



Release Detection

CMR employs process area detectors and perimeter monitors with alarms to detect hydro

carbons, LEL and hydrogen sulfide. These detectors and monitors alert operators in the control room and locally.  



Release Containment/Control

Containment and/or control measures include process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases, valves to permit isolation of the process, the curtailment via diking to contain liquid releases, and redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., independent firewater system).



Release Mitigation

Mitigation equipment includes fire suppression and extinguishing systems, as well as an on-site fire truck and foam cannon . Trained and certified hazardous materials emergency response and industrial firefighting personnel are available. In addition, personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus), fire suppression and extinguishing systems are available including automatic and manual systems in the truck loading and unloading areas and the LPG areas.



Additionally, Calumet maintains internal response capabilities with a paid-on-call response team that is trained in industrial firefighting, hazardous materials response and technical rescue. This team is trained in accordance with NFPA and OSHA standards and maintains a presence in the facility 24/7.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY (40 CFR 68.155 (d) & 40 CR 68.42(b))

CMR continues to strive to minimize the potential for any releases from our plant.  During the past five (5) years there has been one (1) release of note.  For the non-reportable incidents that have occurred CMR personnel responded swiftly to control and contain each release.  CMR investigates every incident very carefully to determine ways to prevent similar incidents from occurring. FCC Fire (NAICS Code 32411)



On March 7, 2019 at 1:35 PM, a vapor cloud ignition occurred due to a release of liquid pressurized gases (LPGs), approximately 2,818 lbs.  The incident resulted from a burst pipe caused by extreme cold weather. It wa

s extinguished in approximately 90 minutes, with minimal onsite impact.  Local responders closed nearby roads.  A precautionary shelter in place was executed offsite but ultimately no offsite impacts were identified.  Offsite responders were standing by to provide back-up firefighting assistance.

Air monitoring did not detect any environmental release either during or after the incident and no injuries were identified. Primary wind direction originated from the East at an average of 2.5 mph. CMR has conducted a survey to identify any lines or equipment which could be subject to failure due to extremely cold conditions.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE (40 CFR 68.155 (e))

CMR maintains an Emergency Response Plan that is coordinated with the City of Great Falls Fire and Rescue Department to provide a carefully planned and effective response effort. CMR employees are also trained in emergency response to incidents involving hazardous substances and drills are conducted periodically to ensure that the emergency response teams can mitigate the effects from a release.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY (40 CFR 68.155 (f))

CMR continues to invest resources in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our facility.  Continuous implementation of CMR's Process Safety Management (PSM) program and Risk Management Program (RMP) are designed to mitigate potential risks that may arise during the design stage through the useful life of the equipment and improve the safety performance of the facility.
